comments.content: The FDP wanted the exchange rate drifting down to 0.5 by 2050. Claims that you don’t have to put in residuals all the way to 2050 are false.
The FDP wanted this drifting down to 1.4% by 2050….
The FDP wanted this drifting down to 2050.

Taken down a lot last time in view of the tariffs and as Jordan is likely to get 10% reciprocal plus 10% baseline, I don’t want to go too high, but Q1 came in at 2.7% yoy, so it has to be higher than 1.9% in the year. The only residuals touched are exports and imports. See the comments there.
This is OK as there has always been a residual.

The data are shown as actuals for the components up to 2023, but if you got to the IFS which the Haver code leads to, you find the last actual was 2007, so the whole components presentation is guesswork at best.
Customs data show goods exports up by 10.6% yoy by value in Jan-April
Customs data show goods imports up by 12.7% yoy by value in Jan-April.
Customs data show goods exports up by 10.6% yoy by value in Jan-April
Customs data show goods imports up by 12.7% yoy by value in Jan-April.

Our previous figure was 20.5%, but then again our previous figures for up to 2024 were over 20% and the decision of the FDP to use “EIU calculations” (er… different from the previous workbook) showing it is 18% is questionable. See https://en.ammonnews.net/article/82070 for a tiny drop in Q1 - but from 21.4% to 21.3%. I think as Q1 had rapid growth and the tariffs point to a slowing the, full year will be higher than 2024.
No good data on this. See Haver where it says the unemployment rate for people over 25 is 63%!!!
10.1% drop in global food prices and oil moving down too.
I’m guided here by global manufactures export prices in GA
I don’t know how to forecast these deflators. My only thought is that the residuals eg in row 12 must be kept low.
My only thought here is that the residuals need to be chosen to keep the residuals in row 6 low.
Taken up slightly in line with forecast for slightly stronger GDP growth
These are quite different from the ones published last time.
Where are these figures from? Or indeed any figures on this?
I’ve eased these down in 2027-29. The workbook was going to have 16.5% in 2029, but as this was only 10.5% in 2023 (if the historic figures are accurate), then I don’t want it zooming up too much.
I have no idea how to forecast this.
Taking fikgures from EMERGEMA --> Jordan --> Financial --> Money Supply (M1 + Quasi-Money = M2) --> Currency in circulation (N439FMC@EMERGEMA)?
EMERGEMA --> Jordan --> Financial --> Domestic Credit by Sector by Currency --> Domestic Credit (N439FMAA@EMERGEMA)
-10.7 is correct
This assumes that after regional wars definitely end, services will improve more
Takes account of tariffs
As 7.4 was  a record in 2023, I don’t want it zooming up too much.
-6% is correct from Haver.
3.2 is correct from EMERGEMA --> Jordan --> International Trade and Balance of Payments --> Current Account --> Credit (N439BTCR@EMERGEMA) but the historic figures don’t match anything.
Up 11.6% yoy in Q1 and up 7.4% in April, but the tariffs make it difficult to be optimistic.
Up 6.6% yoy in Q1 and up 31.3% yoy in April.
I don’t know what to do with an unnamed Export 1.

7.7 in June see EMERGEMA --> Jordan --> International Trade and Balance of Payments --> Foreign Reserves --> Gold (value) (N439LFGL@EMERGEMA) What is going to happen to gold prices? The new FDP has no Global assumptions sheet.
21.0 according to EMERGEMA --> Jordan --> International Trade and Balance of Payments --> Foreign Reserves --> Gross foreign reserves (including Gold and SDRs) (millions of US$) (N439LFF@EMERGEMA)
These are wrong in the IFS. Compare C439IC@IFS and N439RTAR@EMERGEMA  The  correct rate is the latter.
These are wrong in the IFS. Compare C439IC@IFS and N439RTAR@EMERGEMA  The  correct rate is the latter.
These are wrong in the IFS. Compare C439IC@IFS and N439RTAR@EMERGEMA  The  correct rate is the latter.
Raised from 0.2 to take account of new RSF
Raised from 0.2 due to RSF
Raised from 0.2 due to RSF
June 2025—Jordan agrees 30 month RSF of SDR 514m --this is a loan disbursement. SDR0.1bn in H2 2025 and the remainder at 0.2bn a year in 2026-27
Budget figures are including grants.
